title: Cat. 45  Head of a Tahitian with Profile of Second Head to His Right (recto), Two Figures (verso), 1891/93
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Head of a Tahitian with Profile of Second Head to His Right (recto), Two Figures (related to the painting Tahitian Landscape) (verso, fig. 45.1)  
1891/93  
Black and red chalk, selectively stumped (recto); black chalk, with touches of watercolor and watercolor offset (verso); on cream wove paper; 352 × 369 mm  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Emily Crane Chadbourne, 1922.4794R/V  
Rewald 92, Pickvance 69

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">The Tahitian man facing forward on the recto of this sheet relates to a group of charcoal studies of female heads that Gauguin made during his first months in Tahiti (see cat. 49, Descriptive Analysis and Related Works). During his first months there, he purposefully restrained from executing paintings, intent upon learning as much as he could about the island’s people and topography by drawing incessantly, whether on individual sheets or in sketchbooks. His charcoal heads are studies of figures that interested him, although one (cat. 49) can be regarded as a true portrait, since it relates to a depiction in oil of the young woman Gauguin was living with (cat. 50). For the most part, these images reveal the artist abstracting facial features, generalizing countenances rather than individualizing them.

The pupil-less eyes, simplified shape of the eyebrows, and the regularized contour of the man in the Art Institute’s drawing contribute to the masklike quality of the image. The head displays a kinship with a bust-length likeness in oil of an unidentified male sitter, whose facial features are somewhat like those of the subject of the drawing (fig. 45.2 [W 422]). The sitter in the painting, his face turned to the left, seems to have dressed up for his sitting; he wears a pink shirt and blue cravat and has decorated himself further with flowers at his left ear (among them a gardenia).

The head in profile to the left of the charcoal Tahitian male is related to the seated figure in profile depicted in an 1897 oil painting, Te rerioa (The Dream) (fig. 45.3 [W 557]), although the latter faces in the opposite direction. The Chicago drawing brings to mind various depictions of Tahitian male types by Gauguin (see fig. 45.4) and by other artists working in the early twentieth century, such as Walker Evans. Indeed, the title Evans gave to a 1932 photograph of a man—Tahiti—distances the image from the particular individual it represents (fig. 45.5).

The sheet’s verso (see fig. 45.1) is a figure study for Gauguin’s 1892 oil painting Tahitian Landscape (fig. 45.6 [W 442]).  
Peter Zegers

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry2" id="curatorial_entry2">This powerful study of a Tahitian male head is virtually unique in Gauguin’s drawn oeuvre. Fascinated by the serene and contemplative Tahitian women, Gauguin created more monumental portrait drawings of them than of native men. This sheet shares the large scale of his female head studies (see cat. 49), but it distinguishes itself from the group in being the only known male portrait head and in displaying a distinctly different handling of materials. Whereas the female head studies are notable for a rich application of charcoal and black chalk with sometimes rigorous stumping, here Gauguin intermingled red chalk with black chalk, selectively stumping the figure’s face and hair. He established preliminary lines with black and red chalk and reinforced the defining lines of the face with black chalk. Touches of red chalk enhance the man’s lips. Pentimenti reveal an adjustment of the figure’s jaw line, and an old fold may reflect a desire to trim the sheet.

The features of this head have been compared to a relatively early, undated oil portrait ([fig. 45.7 [W 422]) tentatively identified as Anani, Gauguin’s landlord and neighbor in Mataiea, or Jotépha, who helped the artist find wood to make sculpture. But neither identification can be confirmed with certainty. The artist seems not to have used this drawing as the basis for any paintings. He might have intended this drawing, with its impressive scale and degree of finish, for exhibition as an independent work of art, although he declared that his drawings were private, for him. Indeed, its commanding presence explains why it was one of four works by Gauguin included in the 1913 Armory Show, which traveled to the Art Institute of Chicago (see fig. 45.8).

Like several of the large charcoal-and-black-chalk female heads, the frontal portrayal here is accompanied by a slight profile to the left (see, for example, fig. 45.9 [Rewald 119] and fig. 45.10). The turned-up nose and receding chin of the profile on the present sheet, so effortlessly and persuasively conveyed with a simple contour line, suggests it is another figure and not a second view of the main protagonist. Gauguin’s effective circumscription of a profile with a few swelling lines can be seen also in a contemporary sheet, Studies of Striding Figures, Costumes, and the Head in Profile of a Tahitian (fig. 45.11).

The verso of the sheet features studies of two standing figures: a hand and the eyes, brow, and nose of a head turned in a three-quarters view to the right. Although Gauguin seems to have tended to leave eyes undefined (see cat. 32), in this brief sketch, the eyeball is distinctly visible. The two standing Tahitian figures are juxtaposed—one facing forward, the other with her back mostly turned, as they would appear (even closer together) in the 1892 painting Tahitian Landscape (fig. 45.12 [W 442]). A second attempt at the hand of one of the figures reveals Gauguin sensitivity to the accuracy of small details. There are touches of red and blue watercolor on the verso that do not seem to relate to the drawn figures—this color may be off-set from another sheet. Gauguin later turned the sheet over to execute the more finished drawing on the recto. The sheet was folded, just below the chin of the forward facing man. This folding may have been done by Gauguin, or by a later collector, to frame the composition differently or mark where the sheet may be trimmed.  
Suzanne Folds McCullagh

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Emily Crane Chadbourne (1871–1964), London and Chicago, by 1910.

Given by Emily Crane Chadbourne to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1922.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscribed lower left, in graphite: 6798

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The man portrayed on the recto of this drawing closely resembles the figure in Gauguin’s painting Young Man with a Flower (1891; Christie’s, New York, Nov. 9, 2015, lot 6A [W 422]). The two figures on the verso appear in a painting from Gauguin’s first Tahitian voyage, Tahitian Landscape (1892; Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York [W 442]).

Charles F. Stuckey suggested that these two images “perhaps portray Ananai, Gauguin’s landlord and neighbor in Mataiea,” or Jotépha, who led Gauguin into the mountains to find wood to make sculptures; see Stuckey, “Head of a Tahitian with Profile of Second Head to His Right (recto); Two Figures Related to Tahitian Landscape and Head (verso),” in Richard R. Brettell, Françoise Cachin, Claire Frèches-Thory, and Charles F. Stuckey, The Art of Paul Gauguin, with assistance from Peter Zegers, exh. cat. (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C./Art Institute of Chicago/New York Graphic Society, 1988), p. 224, cat. 122.

Tahitian gardenia or tiaré flower (Gardenia taitensis).

Gauguin described the serene quality of Tahitians to his wife Mette soon after his arrival to Tahiti in July 1891: “The natives often move about at night, barefooted and silent. Nothing but this silence. I understand why these people can remain hours and days sitting immobile and gazing sadly at the sky.” In Paul Gauguin: Letters to His Wife and Friends, ed. Maurice Malingue, trans. Henry J. Stenning (World, 1949), p. 163, no. 126.

See Charles F. Stuckey, in Richard Brettell, Françoise Cachin, Claire Frèches-Thory, and Charles F. Stuckey, The Art of Paul Gauguin, with assistance from Peter Zegers, exh. cat. (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C./Art Institute of Chicago/New York Graphic Society Books), p. 224.

Gauguin wrote that his drawings were not to be viewed by critics: “They are my letters, my secrets. The public man, the private man.” Paul Gauguin, “Avant et après (January–February 1903),” in Gauguin, The Writings of a Savage, ed. Daniel Guérin, trans. Eleanor Levieux (Viking, 1974), p. 267.

Charles F. Stuckey suggested it is a female head; Stuckey, “Head of a Tahitian with Profile of Second Head to His Right (recto); Two Figures Related to Tahitian Landscape and Head (verso),” in Richard R. Brettell, Françoise Cachin, Claire Frèches-Thory, and Charles F. Stuckey, The Art of Paul Gauguin, with assistance from Peter Zegers, exh. cat. (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C./Art Institute of Chicago), p. 224, cat. 122. Peter Zegers suggests that this figure is related to the woman seen in the profile in Gauguin's 1897 painting Te rerioa (The Dream) (W 557), see fig. 45.3.

Anna Gruetzner Robins, “‘Manet and the Post-Impressionists’: A Checklist of Exhibits,” Burlington Magazine 152, no. 1293 (Dec. 2010), p. 788.

In her article “‘Manet and the Post-Impressionists’: A Checklist of Exhibits,” Anna Gruetzner Robins notes that Emily Crane Chadbourne’s Gauguin works were in the Grafton Gallery show, but only one can be assigned a specific catalogue number (cat. 64). Robins mentions that six (five works on paper, one is a drawing on the verso and counted as the sixth, see cat. 61, cat. 64, cat. 126, and cat. 129) works by Chadbourne were given to the Art Institute, and these works were certainly in the Grafton Galleries show by deduction: “In 1913 she lent four of these six works by Gauguin to the Armory Show, which suggests that all the Chadbourne Gauguins now in Chicago were in the Grafton Galleries exhibition. “Anna Gruetzner Robins,” ‘Manet and the Post-Impressionists’: A Checklist of Exhibits,” Burlington Magazine 152, no. 1293 (Dec. 2010), p. 788.

Anna Gruetzner Robins, “‘Manet and the Post-Impressionists’: A Checklist of Exhibits,” Burlington Magazine 152, no. 1293 (Dec. 2010), p. 788.

Republished as Gauguin (Dodd, Mead, 1924), pl. 19. A second edition appeared as Robert Rey, Gauguin, 2nd ed. (John Lane the Bodley Head, 1924), pl. 19.

Françoise Cachin, Gauguin (Flammarion, 1990), pp. 148, 303, fig. 155. Reprinted in Françoise Cachin, Gauguin (Flammarion, 1990), pp. 148, 303, fig. 155.3.

fig. 45.11 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Studies of Striding Figures, Costumes, and the Head in Profile of a Tahitian, c. 1892. Graphite on paper; 25.4 × 25.4 cm (10 × 10 in.). fig. 45.2 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Young Man with a Flower behind His Ear, 1891. Oil on canvas; 45.4 × 33.5 cm (17 7/8 × 13 1/4 in.). Christie’s, New York, The Artist’s Muse: An Evening Sale, sale cat. (Christie’s, New York, Nov. 9, 2015), lot 6A.

fig. 45.3 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Te rerioa (The Dream), 1897. Oil on canvas; 95.1 × 130.2 cm (37 3/8 × 51 1/4 in.). The Samuel Courtauld Trust, The Courtauld Gallery, London.

fig. 45.4 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Non dépourvues de sentiment (Not without Feeling), from the manuscript Avant et après (Before and After), 1903. Pen and ink, brush and wash on paper; 29.5 × 21.7 cm (11 9/16 × 8 1/2 in.) (sheet). Location unknown. From Paul Gauguin, Avant et après, facsimile ed. (K. Wolff, 1918), p. 125
